questions.question_text: What is a valid use case for a bar chart?

choices.D: To compare multiple dimensions over an extended period
choices.A: To compare measures across categories at a glance
choices.C: To see individual data points while also viewing associated categories

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: CD
C. They can be continuous or discrete
D. They contain numeric, quantitative values

Selected Answer: CD
The answer is C and D. A and B describe dimensions.

Selected Answer: CD
CD correct
CD is the answer

wrong, the correct answers are CD

Selected Answer: CD
C and D. Measures contain numeric, quantitative values
A is wrong, Measures do not affect the level of detail

Selected Answer: CD
Dimensions contain qualitative values (such as names, dates, or geographical data). Dimensions affect the level of detail in the view. Measures contain numeric, quantitative values that you can measure. They both can be continuous or discrete

questions.question_text: Which two statements accurately describes measures? (Choose two.)

choices.C: They can be continuous or discrete
choices.A: They affect the level of detail in the view

questions.question_text:
You have a field named Region in a data source Region contains the following values:

North -

East -

South -

West -
You need to ensure that Region always sorts in the order of East, South, North, and West when placed onto any worksheet.
What should you use?

choices.D: The Default Properties of the field from the Data pane
choices.A: The Sort indicator on the axis
choices.B: The Sort menu on the legend

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: BC
B. The Dashboard menu
C. The Dashboard pane

questions.question_text: Which two options can you use to change the device layout of a dashboard? (Choose two.)

choices.C: Names of regions such as East, West, and so on
choices.B: Numerical totals such as test scores, sales and profit totals, and so on
choices.A: Names of people such as students, customers, and so on

Selected Answer: AB
Dimensions contain qualitative values (such as names, dates, or geographical data). You can use dimensions to categorize, segment, and reveal the details in your data. Dimensions affect the level of detail in the view
